projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ARTICLES OF ALLIANCE and COMMERCE, Between The mo≈øt Serene and Potent PRINCE CHARLES II.
By the Grace of God, King of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
AND THE Mo≈øt Serene and Potent Prince CHRISTIAN V.
By the Grace of God, King of Denmark, Norway, &c. Concluded at Copenhagen, the 11th. day of July. 1670.
In the SAVOY, Printed by the A≈ø≈øigns of John Bill, and Chri≈øtopher Barker, Printers to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, 1671/2.

div.head: Articles of Alliance and Commerce between the Mo≈øt Serene and Potent Prince, Charles the Second, By the Grace of God, King of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c. and the Mo≈øt Serene and Potent Prince Chri≈øtian the Fifth, by the Grace of God, King of Denmak, Norway, &c. Concluded at Copenhagen, the 11th. day of July. 1670.
I.
div.p:
THat there be between the two Kings, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors; As al≈øo their Kingdoms, Principalities, Provinces, E≈øtates, Counties, I≈ølands, Cities, Subjects and Va≈ø≈øals of what condition, dignity and degree ≈øoever, by Land and Sea, in Rivers, Fre≈øh Waters, and all places what≈øoever as well in Europe, as out of Europe; now and for the time
to come, a ≈øincere, true and perfect friend≈øhip, Peace and Confederation; So as that neither party do any wrong, injury or prejudice to the Kingdoms, Principalities, Provinces, and E≈øtates, or to the inhabitants and Subjects of the other; nor ≈øuffer any to be done by others, as much as in him is: But rather live as friends together, u≈øing each other, with good will and re≈øpect; And promoting upon all occa≈øions the intere≈øts, and advantages of each other, and their ≈øubjects, as if they were their own: And Preventing and hindring with all their power, by their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and Advice, any damage, wrong and injury that may be offered them.

div.head: II.
div.p: Neither of the fore≈øaid Kings and their Heirs ≈øhall con≈øent to any thing, that may be to the prejudice or detriment of his Allie; but if either of the Kings ≈øhall know that any thing is propo≈øed, or is in agitation or contrivance, or that will be propo≈øed, agitated or contrived which may tend to the detriment of the other; He ≈øhall be obliged to ≈øignify the ≈øame unto Him without delay, and in the mean time to hinder and prevent it by all ways po≈ø≈øible.

div.head: III.
div.p:
The fore≈øaid Kings for them≈øelves, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors mutually do undertake and promi≈øe, that they will not aide or furni≈øh the Enemies of either party, that ≈øhall be Aggre≈ø≈øors, with any Provi≈øions
of War, as Souldiers, Arms, Engines, Guns, Ships, or other nece≈ø≈øaries for the u≈øe of War, or ≈øuffer any to be furni≈øhed by their Subjects: But if the Subjects of either Prince ≈øhall pr≈øeume to act contrary hereunto, then that King, who≈øe Subjects ≈øhall have ≈øo done, ≈øhall be obliged to proceed again≈øt them with the highe≈øt ≈øeverity, as again≈øt ≈øeditious per≈øons and breakers of the League.

div.head: IV.
div.p: It is further Covenanted and Argeed; That if at any time hereafter, Any Prince or State ≈øhall invade, or by any ho≈øtile way Attempt upon the Hereditary Kingdomes, Provinces, Counties, Towns, I≈ølands, Territories, or Dominions of the King of Denmark which he now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth, then the King of Great Britain ≈øhall A≈ø≈øi≈øt the ≈øaid King of Denmark in time, with ≈øuch number of Land-forces and Ships of War, again≈øt ≈øuch Aggre≈ø≈øor, as ≈øhall ≈øuffice to repell the force, and as the ≈øtate of the ≈øaid Kings affaires ≈øhall require: And the ≈øaid King of Great Britain ≈øhall therefore with all his power endeavour to hinder, that by ≈øuch inva≈øion or di≈øturbance the King of Denmark be not prejudiced in any wi≈øe in his Kingdoms, Dominions or Rights. And if the ≈øaid King of Great Britain, or the ≈øaid King of Denmark, ≈øhall contract or make any League, Alliance or Union with any other King, Prince, Commonwealth or State, they ≈øhall re≈øpectively endeavour to comprehend therein each other and their Dominions, (as much as in them lies) if they ≈øhall de≈øire to be comprehended.

div.head: V.
div.p: It ≈øhall be lawful for the Subjects of both Kings with their Commodities and Merchandi≈øe both by Sea and Land, in time of Peace without licence or ≈øafe Conduct General or ≈øpecial to come to the Kingdoms, Provinces, Mart-towns, Ports and Rivers of each other, and in any place therein to remain and trade, Paying U≈øual Cu≈øtoms and Duties; Re≈øerving neverthele≈øs to either Prince his Superiority, and Regal juri≈ødiction in his kingdoms, Provinces, Principalities and Territories re≈øpectively.

div.head: VI.
div.p: It is notwith≈øtanding Covenanted and Concluded, That the Subjects of the King of Great Britain ≈øhall in no wi≈øe come to the Prohibited Ports, of which mention is made in Precedent Treaties, nor Colonies, without the Special Licence of the King of Denmark fir≈øt de≈øired and obtained; unle≈øs they ≈øhall be compelled to make thither, and enter therein, by ≈øtre≈øs of Weather, or pur≈øuit of Pirates, in which ca≈øe neither ≈øhall it be lawfull for them to buy or ≈øell. As al≈øo in like manner the Subjects of the King of Denmark ≈øhall not come to the Briti≈øh Colonies, unle≈øs by Special Licence of the King of Great Britain fir≈øt de≈øired and obtained.

div.head: VII.
div.p: It ≈øhall be lawful for the Subjects of the Mo≈øt Serene King of Denmark to bring into their own Stores and Ware-hou≈øes in England, Scotland and Ireland, and other the Ports of the King of Great Britain in Europe, ≈øuch Commodities as now, or hereafter, ≈øhall be of the growth and production of the E≈øtates, Countries and Dominions Subject to the King of Denmark, or of the Manufacture thereof, and likewi≈øe ≈øuch as come from any part of the River of Elbe.

In like manner ≈øhall it be lawfull for the Subjects of the King of Great Britain to import and bring into Denmak, Norway, and all other Ports and Colonies not prohibited of the King of Denmark, all kinds of Merchandi≈øe, which now or hereafter ≈øhall be produced or made in the Kingdoms, Countries and E≈øtates under the Subjection of the King of Great Britain. But if at any time hereafter it be permitted to any forrein Nations, to bring all kinds of Commodities without exception into England, Scotland and Ireland, and other the Ports belonging to the King of Great Brittain, then the ≈øame al≈øo ≈øhall be lawfull for the Subjects of the King of Denmark: Which in like manner ≈øhall be permitted to the Subjects of the King of Great Britain, upon the like occa≈øion, in the Prohibited Ports and Colonies of the King of Denmark.

div.head: VIII.
div.p:
It is al≈øo Covenanted and agreed, that the people
and Subjects of the King of Great Britain, Sailing to any the Hereditary Kingdoms, Countries, or Dominions, of the King of Denmark, or trading in the ≈øame, ≈øhall pay no more or greater Cu≈øtoms, Tribute, toll or other Duties, nor in any other manner, then the People of the United Provinces of the Lowcountries, and other ≈øtrangers, (the Swede onely excepted) trading thither, and Paying le≈ø≈øer Cu≈øtoms, do or ≈øhall pay; And in going, returning, and ≈øtaying, as al≈øo in fi≈øhing and trading, and all other things ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øame Liberties, Immunities, and Priviledges, which the People of any forrein Countrey in the ≈øaid Kingdoms, and Dominions of the King of Denmark, abiding and trading, do or ≈øhall enjoy: And ≈øo on the other ≈øide the People and Subjects of the King of Denmark, ≈øhall have and enjoy the ≈øame Priviledges, in the Countries, and Territories, of the King of Great Britain, to wit, that the People and Subjects of the King of Denmark, Sailing to any the Kingdoms, Countries, or Dominions of the King of Great Britain, or trading in the ≈øame, ≈øhall not pay any more or greater Cu≈øtoms, Tributes, Toll, or other Duties, nor in any other manner, then the People of the United-netherlands, or other Strangers trading thither and paying le≈ø≈øer Cu≈øtoms, do or ≈øhall pay: And in going, returning and ≈øtaying, as al≈øo in fi≈øhing, and trading, and all other things ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øame Liberties, Immunities and Priviledges, which the People of any other Forrein Country, in the ≈øaid Kingdoms, and Dominions of the King of Great Britain, abiding and trading, do or ≈øhall enjoy: But ≈øo, as that the Power
of each King of Making or Altering Cu≈øtoms, or other Duties, as they ≈øhall ≈øee occa≈øion, in their re≈øpective Kingdoms, Countries, Dominions, and Ports, remain full and entire; Provided the fore≈øaid equality be ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved on both ≈øides in manner afore≈øaid.

div.head: IX.
div.p: It is al≈øo covenanted that when the Subjects of either King have imported their Commodities into the Dominions of the other, have Paid the u≈øual Cu≈øtoms for them and undergone their Search, it ≈øhall be free and lawfull for them, to bring their ≈øaid Commodities into their own proper Storehou≈øes, and Cellars, or into places which they ≈øhall think mo≈øt fit and convenient, and there Store them; Nor ≈øhall any Magi≈øtrate or Officer of any the Cities or Ports of either impo≈øe upon them any Cellars or Storehou≈øes without their con≈øent.

div.head: X.
div.p:
The Subjects of either Crown trading upon the Seas, and Sailing by the Coa≈øts of either Kingdom, ≈øhall not be obliged to come into any Port, if their cour≈øe were not directed thither; but ≈øhall have liberty to pur≈øue their Voyage without hindrance or detention whither≈øoever they plea≈øe. Nor ≈øhall they, being by tempe≈øt forced into Port, and there remaining, be obliged to unlade their Cargo, or to barter or ≈øell any part thereof; But it ≈øhall be lawfull for
them, to di≈øpo≈øe of it as they ≈øhall think fit, and to do any other thing, which they ≈øhall judge mo≈øt for their advantage: Provided nothing be done that may be to the defrauding of either Prince of his due Rights and Cu≈øtoms.

div.head: XI.
div.p: It is al≈øo agreed, That after any Planks, Ma≈øts, and other ≈øorts of Timber, have been once put on board the Ships of the Subjects or People of the King of Great Britain, they ≈øhall not be liable to any further Search; But all Search, or ≈øcrutiny, ≈øhall be made before; And if then, either Oaken or other prohibited Timber be found, it ≈øhall be pre≈øently ≈øtop'd and detained upon the place before it be put on board the Ships; Nor ≈øhall the People of the ≈øaid King of Great Britain, or his Subjects, be therefore mole≈øted in their Per≈øons or E≈øtates by Arre≈øt, or other detention what≈øoever; But onely the Subjects of the King of Denmark, who ≈øhall have pre≈øumed to Sell or Alienate any the like prohibited Timber, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed in due manner. And the People and Subjects of the King of Great Britain, ≈øhall have, po≈ø≈øe≈øs and enjoy all and ≈øingular the contents, and conce≈ø≈øions of this Article, without any Mole≈øtation or Interruption, ≈øo long and for all ≈øuch time as the Subjects or any of the People of the United Netherlands, ≈øhall hold, po≈ø≈øe≈øs, and enjoy, or might, or ought to hold, po≈ø≈øe≈øs, and enjoy the ≈øame or like priviledges by any Treaty already made, or to be made, or by any Contract, Agreement or permi≈ø≈øion.

div.head: XII.
div.p: It is al≈øo Conluded and Agreed, That all Ships belonging to the Subjects of the King of Great Britain, and Merchants in their pa≈ø≈øage through the Soundt under the Mo≈øt Serene King of Denmark and Norway, &c. ≈øhall enjoy after the ≈øame manner the Benefit and Priviledge of deferring the Payment of their Cu≈øtoms until their return, as they held and enjoyed in former years la≈øt preceding the late War; But ≈øo neverthele≈øs, that the ≈øaid Ships and Merchants bring with them Certificates under the Seal of the Officers of the ≈øaid King of Great Britain deputed thereunto, te≈øtifying the ≈øaid Ships to belong to Subjects of the King of Great Britain; And likewi≈øe that before their pa≈ø≈øage they give ≈øufficient and good ≈øecurity for paying the ≈øame in place convenient to the Collectors of the Cu≈øtoms of the ≈øaid King of Denmark, at their return, or if they ≈øhall not return, within three moneths time at the furthe≈øt, if they do not pay the ≈øame at their ≈øaid fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øage.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
And furthermore it is Agreed, that what≈øoever Merchandi≈øe, the Subjects of the King of Great Britain, ≈øhall land at El≈øignore, and there lay in their Storehou≈øes, to no other end, then to put on board again entire, and tran≈øport them to other parts, they ≈øhall be obliged to pay onely the ≈øame duties for ≈øuch Merchandi≈øe, and no more, then is wont to be paid in this
ca≈øe by the Dutch Nation or any other Strangers: Which ≈øhall be reciprocally ob≈øerved to the Subjects of the King of Denmark after the ≈øame manner in England.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: Al≈øo it is Agreed, that the Ships and Subjects of the King of Great Britain, ≈øhall have their di≈øpatch at El≈øignore, as ≈øoon as they arrive there without delay, No Ships of what Nation ≈øoever having preference before them in this behalf: Except the Inhabitants of certain places, who have anciently held a priviledge to that purpo≈øe, and ≈øtill do.

div.head: XV.
div.p:
If any Subject of either Prince ≈øhall happen to die in the Dominions, or Territories of the other, it ≈øhall be lawful for him to di≈øpo≈øe of his e≈øtate, both money and goods in any manner what≈øoever: And if any one die within the Kingdoms, or Provinces of the other Prince without making any ≈øuch di≈øpo≈øitions then the Goods by him left, moveable or immoveable, of whatever nature or condition the ≈øame ≈øhall be, ≈øhall be faithfully pre≈øerved for the u≈øe of the right Heir, and for ≈øatisfaction of ≈øuch debts as the party decea≈øed was ju≈øtly bound to pay: And to that end, ≈øo ≈øoon as any Subject of either Prince ≈øhall die in the other Princes Dominions, the Con≈øul or Publick Mini≈øter then re≈øiding there, ≈øhall have right to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the ≈øaid Moneys and Goods, and ≈øhall make Inventories of the ≈øame before ≈øome Magi≈øtrate of the place; Which Goods ≈øhall afterwards remain in his hands, to be an≈øwered
to the Heirs and Creditors as afore≈øaid; But if no ≈øuch Con≈øul or Publick Mini≈øter ≈øhall be there, then it ≈øhall be lawful for two Merchants of the ≈øame Countrey with the party decea≈øed to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Goods left by him, to pre≈øerve them, and in like manner to an≈øwer them to the Heirs and Creditors. Which notwith≈øtanding is to be ≈øo under≈øtood, that no Papers, or Books of Accounts are by this Article to be expo≈øed to the in≈øpection of the ≈øaid Magi≈øtrate, but onely the real Goods and Merchandi≈øe of the decea≈øed; And that the ≈øaid Magi≈øtrate within the ≈øpace of fourty eight hours, after notice given and reque≈øt made, ≈øhall be obliged to be pre≈øent, otherwi≈øe the ≈øaid Inventories ≈øhall be made without him.

div.head: XVI.
div.p: It ≈øhall be lawfull for either of the Confederates and their Subjects or People to Trade with the Enemies of the other, and to carry to them, or furni≈øh them with any Merchandi≈øes (Prohibited onely, which they call Contrabanda, excepted) without any impediment, unle≈øs in Ports and Places be≈øieged by the other; Which neverthele≈øs if they ≈øhall ≈øo do; it ≈øhall be free for them either to ≈øell their Goods to the Be≈øiegers, or betake them≈øelves to any other Port or Place not be≈øieged.

div.head: XVII.
div.p:
It is al≈øo Agreed, That it ≈øhall be free and lawfull for the Subjects of either Prince, Trading in the Dominions
or Ports of the other, there to remain, and re≈øide for the buying and ≈øelling Commodities, without any re≈øtriction of time or limitation to be impo≈øed upon them by any Officers or Magi≈øtrates of the ≈øaid Dominions or Ports, They Paying the accu≈øtomed Duties for all Goods and Merchandi≈øe by them imported, or exported; And further provided that they trade with none, but ≈øuch as are Citizens, or Burgers of ≈øome City, or Town, within the Kingdoms of Denmark or Norway, and that onely by whole-≈øale, and not by parcells or retail.

div.head: XVIII.
div.p: Furthermore, for the better encouragement of Trade and Commerce, and for the utter avoiding of all Frauds and Di≈øputes that may ari≈øe between the Officers of Ports and Merchants, It is Agreed and Concluded, That all and ≈øingular Duties ≈øhall be demanded and paid according to the Printed Tariffe, (or Book of Rates) wherein ≈øhall be compri≈øed all Cu≈øtomes and Duties to be paid as well for Goods in the re≈øpective Ports, as for pa≈ø≈øage through the Soundt: And to the end that this may be the more Strictly ob≈øerved, Both Kings ≈øhall not onely enjoyn his Officers and Collectors of his Cu≈øtomes under the highe≈øt penalty, not to do any thing that may fru≈øtrate or elude this Agreement; But al≈øo that they do not by Mole≈øtation or Exaction, cau≈øe any trouble, or offer any injury to the Subjects of either King.

div.head: XIX.
div.p: Moreover, it is concluded and Agreed, That the King of Denmark ≈øhall con≈øtitute the Over≈øeers of his Cu≈øtoms or others, Commi≈ø≈øioners for re-mea≈øuring all Ships belonging to the Subjects of the King of Great Britain Trading in Norway, according to their burden and content, ≈øo as that what has been hitherto not rightly ob≈øerved, either in exce≈øs or defect, may be hereafter reduced into better Order.

div.head: XX.
div.p: But le≈øt ≈øuch freedom of Navigation or Pa≈ø≈øage of the One Allie and His Subjects and People, during the War that the other may have by Sea, or Land with any other Countrey, may be to the prejudice of the other Allie, and that Goods and Merchandi≈øe belonging to the enemy, may be fraudulently concealed under colour of being in Amity; For the preventing of fraud, and clearing all ≈øu≈øpition, It is thought fit, that the Ships, Goods and Men belonging to the other Confederate in their pa≈ø≈øage and Voyages, be accompanied with Letters of Pa≈ø≈øe-port and Certi≈øicate; The forms whereof to be as follows;

body.head: CHARLES the Second by the Grace of God, King of Great Britain, &c.
CHRISTIAN the Fifth by the Grace of God, King of Denmark and Norway, &c.
body.p:
BE it known unto all and ≈øingular to whom the≈øe Our Letters of Safe-conduct ≈øhall be ≈øhewn; That _____ Our Subject and Citizen of Our City of _____ hath humbly repre≈øented unto Us, that the Ship called _____ of the burthen of _____ Tuns, doth belong unto them and others our Subjects, and that they are ≈øole Owners and Proprietors thereof, and is now Laden with the Goods which are contained in a Schedule which ≈øhe hath with her from the Officers of our Cu≈øtoms, and do Solely, Truly and Really belong to Our Subjects or others in Neutrality, bound immediately from the Port of _____ to ≈øuch other place or places, where ≈øhe may conveniently Trade with the ≈øaid Goods, being not Prohibited nor belonging to either of the parties in ho≈øtility, or el≈øe find a Freight, Which the fore≈øaid _____ Our Subject having atte≈øted by a writing under his hand, and affirmed to be true by Oath, under Penalty of confi≈øcation of the ≈øaid Goods, We have thought fit to grant him the≈øe our Letters Of Safe-conduct: And therefore We do hereby re≈øpectively Pray and de≈øire All Governors of Countries and Seas, Kings, Princes, Commonwealths, and free Cities, and more e≈øpecially the Parties now in War, and their Commanders, Admiralls,
Generalls, Officers, Governours of Ports, Commanders of Ships, Captains, Freighters and all others what≈øoever having any Juri≈ødiction by Sea, or the Cu≈øtody of any Port, whom the Ship afore≈øaid ≈øhall chance to meet, or among who≈øe Fleet or Ships it ≈øhall happen to fall or make ≈øtay in their Ports, that by vertue of the League and Amity, which we have with any King or State, they ≈øuffer the ≈øaid Ma≈øter with the Ship _____ per≈øons, things, and all Merchandi≈øe on board her, not onely freely and without any Mole≈øtation, Detention, or Impediment to any place what≈øoever to pur≈øue his Voyage, but al≈øo to afford him all Offices of Civility as to Our Subject if there ≈øhall be occa≈øion; Which upon the like or other occa≈øion, We and Ours ≈øhall be ready to return.

dateline.hi: Given the _____ day of _____ in the year

body.p: WE the Pre≈øident, Con≈øuls and Senators of the City of _____ do Atte≈øt and Certifie, That on the _____ day of _____ in the year _____ Per≈øonally before us came and appeared _____ Citizen and Inhabitant of the City or Town of _____ and under the Oath wherein he ≈øtands bound to Our Sovereign Lord the King, did declare unto us, That the Ship or Ve≈ø≈øell called _____ of the burthen of _____ Tuns doth belong to the Port, City or Town of _____ in the Province of _____ And that the ≈øaid Ship doth ju≈øtly belong onely to him and others, Subjects of Our ≈øaid Sovereign Lord, and now bound directly from the Port of _____ laden with the Goods mentioned in a Schedule received from the Officers of the Cu≈øtoms, and that he hath affirmed under the Oath afore≈øaid, that the forementioned Ve≈ø≈øell with her Goods and Merchandi≈øe doth onely belong to Subjects of His Maje≈øtie, and doth carry no Goods prohibited, which belong to either of the Parties now in War.

p.hi: In te≈øtimony whereof we have cau≈øed this Certificate to be Sub≈øcribed by the Syndic of Our City, and ≈øealed with Our Seal.

div.p: When therefore the Merchandi≈øe, Goods, Ships, or Men of either of the Confederates and their Subjects and People, ≈øhall meet in open Sea, Streights, Ports, Havens, Lands and places what≈øoever, the Ships of War, whether Publick or Private, or the Men, Subjects and People of the other Confederate; Upon exhibiting onely the fore≈øaid Letters of Safe-conduct and Certificate, there ≈øhall be nothing more required of them, nor ≈øhall Search be made after the Goods, Ships or Men, nor ≈øhall they be any other ways what≈øoever mole≈øted or troubled; But ≈øuffered with all freedome to pur≈øue their intended Voyage; But if this ≈øolemne and ≈øet form of Pa≈ø≈øeport and Certificate be not exhibited, or that there be any other ju≈øt and urgent cau≈øe of Su≈øpition; Then ≈øhall the Ship be Searched, which is neverthele≈øs in this ca≈øe onely under≈øtood to be permitted, and not otherwi≈øe. If by either party any thing ≈øhall be committed contrary to the true meaning of this Article, again≈øt either of the Confederates, each of the ≈øaid Confederates ≈øhall cau≈øe His Subjects and People offending to be ≈øeverely puni≈øhed, and full and entire ≈øatisfaction to be forthwith given, and without delay, to the party injured and His Subjects and People for their whole lo≈øs and expences.

div.head: XXI.
div.p:
It is al≈øo concluded and Agreed, that all Ships of Subjects and People of the King of Great Britain together with their lading and Merchandi≈øe, pa≈ø≈øing by
the Port of Gluck≈øtad, or other Places and Towns, under the Dominion of the King of Denmark, ≈øituate upon the Elve-≈øtream, both going and returning, ≈øhall be free and exempt from all Cu≈øtome, Impo≈øt, Search, Sei≈øure, and Mole≈øtation, except onely the ca≈øe of Search in the time of War, when the King of Denmark hath War with any other King or State.

div.head: XXII.
div.p: If the Subjects of either Prince be hurt or injured in the Territories of the other; Then the King of that place where the injury is done, ≈øhall take care that ≈øpeedy ju≈øtice be admini≈øtred according to the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of the Country; And that the per≈øons guilty be duely puni≈øhed, with ≈øatisfaction to be made to the party wronged.

div.head: XXIII.
div.p: It is al≈øo Agreed, That no ≈øhips what≈øoever, Ve≈ø≈øels, or Merchandi≈øe laden on ≈øhips of what≈øoever nature kind or quality, how≈øoever taken, belonging to any the Subjects of either of the afore≈øaid Kings, under any colour or pretence what≈øoever be adjudged Pri≈øe, unle≈øs by a Judicial Examination and Proce≈øs in form of Law, in a Court of Admiralty for Pri≈øes taken at Sea in that behalf lawfully Con≈øtituted.

div.head: XXIV.
div.p:
Both parties ≈øhall cau≈øe ju≈øtice and equity to be
Admini≈øtred to the Subjects and People of each other, according to the Laws and Statutes of either Countrey, Speedily, and without long and unnece≈ø≈øary formalities of Law and expences, in all cau≈øes and Controver≈øies, as well now depending, as which may hereafter ari≈øe.

div.head: XXV.
div.p:
If the ≈øhips of either of the Confederates, and their Subjects and People, whether they be Merchant Men, or Men of War, ≈øhall happen to run on ground, or fall upon Rocks, or be forced to lighten them≈øelves, or ≈øhall otherwi≈øe ≈øuffer Ship-wrack (which God forbid) upon the Coa≈øts of either King, the fore≈øaid Ships with their tackle, Goods, and Merchandi≈øe, or what≈øoever ≈øhall be remaining of them, ≈øhall be Re≈øtored to their owners and Proprietors; Provided they or their Agents and Proctors do claim the ≈øaid ≈øhips and Goods, within the ≈øpace of a year and a day after ≈øuch Ship-wrack ≈øuffered, ≈øaving always the Rights and Cu≈øtoms of both Nations. The Subjects al≈øo and Inhabitants dwelling upon the ≈øaid Coa≈øts and Shores, ≈øhall be obliged to come in to their help in ca≈øe of danger, and as much as in them lies to give their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; And ≈øhall do their utmo≈øt endeavour, either for the freeing of the Ship, or ≈øaving the Goods, Merchandi≈øe and Apparel of the ≈øaid Ship, and what el≈øe of the ≈øame they ≈øhall be able, and for the conveying the ≈øame into ≈øome ≈øafe place in order to be re≈øtored to the Owners; They paying Salvage, and giving ≈øuch recompence to the per≈øons by who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance
and diligence the ≈øaid Merchandi≈øe and Goods, ≈øhall have been recovered and pre≈øerved as they ≈øhall de≈øerve. And finally both Parties, in ca≈øe of ≈øuch misfortune ≈øhall ≈øee ob≈øerved on their ≈øide, what they would de≈øire to have ob≈øerved and done on the other ≈øide.

div.head: XXVI.
div.p: The Commanders of Ships, or Governours, Souldiers, Marriners and Company belonging to the ≈øame; As al≈øo the Ships them≈øelves, and the Goods and Merchandi≈øe on board them, ≈øhall not be detained by any Arre≈øt or Sei≈øure upon any Warrant either General or Special, or for any cau≈øe, unle≈øs for the defence and pre≈øervation of the Kingdom; Which yet ≈øhall not be under≈øtood to be meant of Arre≈øts layed by Authority of law, for debt contracted upon any other lawful occa≈øion what≈øoever, in which ca≈øe it ≈øhall be lawful to proceed according to the rules of ju≈øtice and Law.

div.head: XXVII.
div.p:
It ≈øhall be free for the Merchants of both Kingdomes, their Factors and ≈øervants, and al≈øo the Ma≈øters and Marriners of Ships upon the Sea, and in other Waters, as likewi≈øe in the Ports, and upon the Coa≈øts and Lands of either Confederate, going, returning and walking, for the defence of their Per≈øons and Goods, to carry any kind of portable Arms, as well offen≈øive as defen≈øive, ≈øo that they give no ju≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpition to the Commanders and Magi≈øtrates of
any place, of any Plots or Contrivances again≈øt the Publick or private Peace.

div.head: XXVIII.
div.p: The Convoys or Ships of War of either Party, meeting in their Voyage, or overtaking any Merchant Ships, or others belonging to the other Confederate or His Subjects, and making the ≈øame cour≈øe at Sea, in Europe or out of Europe, ≈øhall be obliged to guard and defend them as long as they ≈øhall hold the ≈øame cour≈øe together.

div.head: XXIX.
div.p: For the greater ≈øecurity of Commerce and freedom of Navigation, it is Concluded and Agreed, That neither Part, as much as may be, and ≈øhall lie in their powers, ≈øhall permit that Publique Pirates or other Robbers upon the Sea, in any the Ports of the other Kingdom or Country have their Receptacles or Retreats, or ≈øhall ≈øuffer that any of the Inhabitants, or People of either Prince, do receive them into their hou≈øes, or ≈øupply them with provi≈øions, or be otherwi≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øting to them; But on the contrary ≈øhall endeavour, that the ≈øaid Pirates or Robbers and their Parti≈øans and Accomplices be apprehended, and puni≈øhed according to their demerit, and the Ships and Goods, as much as can be found of them, re≈øtored to the lawful Owners or their Agents, Provided their right be made appear by due proof of law in the Court of Admiralty.

div.head: XXX.
div.p:
It is concluded and Agreed, that there ≈øhall be at all times free acce≈øs for the Subjects and People of either Party, to the Ports and Coa≈øts of both Princes, and it ≈øhall be lawful for them to remain therein, and from thence again to depart, and al≈øo to pa≈øs through the Seas and Territories what≈øoever of either King re≈øpectively (Not committing any wa≈øte or injury) not onely with Merchant Ships and Ships of burthen, but al≈øo with Ships of War, whether the ≈øame be upon the Publick account, or Acting by private Commi≈ø≈øions; whether they enter by rea≈øon of Tempe≈øt, and for avoiding the danger of the Sea, or to refit or buy provi≈øions: So that they exceed not the number of ≈øix Ships of War, if they enter of their own accord, nor ≈øhall they remain longer in or about the Ports, then ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary for the refitting of their Ships, buying provi≈øions or other nece≈ø≈øaries: And if they ≈øhould upon occa≈øion de≈øire to come into the ≈øaid Ports with a greater number of Ships of War, It ≈øhall in no wi≈øe be lawful for them to enter therein to without fir≈øt giving timely notice by Letter of their coming, and obtaining leave of tho≈øe to whom the fore≈øaid Ports belong. But if by force of Tempe≈øt or other urgent nece≈ø≈øity, they ≈øhall be compelled to put into harbour, in ≈øuch ca≈øe without any precedent notice, the Ships ≈øhall not be re≈øtrained to a certain number; But with this condition neverthele≈øs, that their Admiral or Commander in chief pre≈øently after his Arrival, ≈øhall make acquainted the chief Magi≈øtrate or
Commander of the Place, Haven or Coa≈øt, whether they are come, with the cau≈øe of his coming; Nor ≈øhall be ≈øtay longer there, then ≈øhall be permitted him by the chief Magi≈øtrate or Commander, and ≈øhall not act or attempt any Ho≈øtility in the Ports whereinto he hath betaken him≈øelf, or any thing prejudicial to him of the Two Confederates to whom they ≈øhall belong.

div.head: XXXI.
div.p: It ≈øhall not be lawful for the Subjects of either King, or the Inhabitants of the Kingdoms or Lands under their obedience, to procure of any Prince or State who is at difference, or in open War with either of the Confederates, Letters Patents, called Commi≈ø≈øions or Repri≈øals, much le≈øs by virtue of ≈øuch Letters to mole≈øt or damnify the Subjects of either. Both the ≈øaid Kings ≈øhall ≈øtrictly prohibite their Subjects re≈øpectively, that they do not procure or accept from other Princes or States any ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øions; But ≈øhall as much as in them lies, forbid and hinder the committing of any depredations by virtue of ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øions.

div.head: XXXII.
div.p:
If any Ship or Ships belonging to the Subjects of either King be taken in the Ports of either by a third party, they in who≈øe Port, or within who≈øe juri≈ødiction what≈øoever the fore≈øaid Ships ≈øhall be taken, ≈øhall be mutually obliged to u≈øe their endeavour together with the other party, for the finding and
retaking the ≈øaid Ships or Ships, and re≈øtoring them to the Owners; Which neverthele≈øs ≈øhall be done at the charge of the ≈øaid Owners, or the Parties interre≈øted.

div.head: XXXIII.
div.p: But if al≈øo in the Ships taken by the Subjects of either Confederate, and brought into any Port belonging to the other, there be found any Seamen or other Per≈øons who are Subjects of that Confederate into who≈øe Ports or Rivers the prize ≈øhall be brought, they ≈øhall be civilly u≈øed by tho≈øe who have taken them, and re≈øtored to their liberty forthwith and without ran≈øome.

div.head: XXXIV.
div.p: But if a Ship of War or any other laden with prohibited Goods belonging to the other Crown happen to be taken; It ≈øhall not be lawful for the Captains or Commanders who have taken her to open or break up any Che≈øts, Tons or Bails on board the ≈øaid Ship, nor likewi≈øe to tran≈øport or otherwi≈øe alienate any of her Merchandi≈øe, until they have been fir≈øt put on ≈øhore, and an Inventory thereof made before the Judges of the Admiralty.

div.head: XXXV.
div.p:
And for the greater ≈øecurity of the Subjects of both Kings, and for preventing of all violence towards them from the ≈øaid Ships of War; All Commanders of any
the Ships of War belonging to the King of Great Britain and all other His Subjects what≈øoever, ≈øhall be ≈øtrictly charged and required, that they do not Mole≈øt or Injure the Subjects of the King of Denmark; If they ≈øhall do otherwi≈øe, they ≈øhall be liable to an≈øwer it in their Per≈øons and E≈øtates, and ≈øhall therein ≈øtand bound until ju≈øt Satisfaction and Compen≈øation ≈øhall be made for the wrongs by them done, and the Damage thereby ≈øu≈øtained or to be ≈øu≈øtained: In like manner, ≈øhall all Commanders of the Ships of War belonging to the King of Denmark, and all other His Subjects what≈øoever be ≈øtraitly under the ≈øame penalties charged and required that they do not mole≈øt or injure the ≈øaid Subjects of the King of Great Britain; Provided neverthele≈øs, that all the fore≈øaid actions be examined and adjudged by due and legal proceeding in the Court of Admiralty of both Kings; Or if it ≈øhall rather ≈øeem meet to either of the parties, being a ≈øtranger in the place where the controver≈øy is to be decided, they ≈øhall be examined before certain Commi≈ø≈øioners, which both Kings ≈øo ≈øoon as they ≈øhall be de≈øired, ≈øhall appoint to that end, that ≈øo proceedings by this means may be not onely carried on without great expen≈øes, but al≈øo ended within three moneths at furthe≈øt.

div.head: XXXVI.
div.p:
Both Kings ≈øhall take care, That judgment and ≈øentence in things taken at Sea, be given according to the rules of ju≈øtice and equity by per≈øons not ≈øu≈øpected or interre≈øted, and being once given by ≈øuch Judges as
afore≈øaid, they ≈øhall ≈øtraitly charge and require their Officers and whom it ≈øhall concern, to ≈øee the ≈øame put in due execution according to the form and tenour thereof.

div.head: XXXVII.
div.p: If the Amba≈ø≈øadors of either King, or any other Publick Mini≈øters re≈øiding with the other King, ≈øhall happen to make complaint of any ≈øuch ≈øentence, that King to whom complaint ≈øhall be made, ≈øhall cau≈øe the ≈øaid judgment and ≈øentence to be reheard and examined in His Council; That it may appear, whether all things requi≈øite and nece≈ø≈øary have been performed according to the rules of this Treaty and with due caution: If the contrary ≈øhall happen, it ≈øhall be redre≈ø≈øed, which is to be done at the furthe≈øt within three moneths time.

Neither ≈øhall it be lawful either before the giving of the fir≈øt ≈øentence, or afterwards during the time of Re-hearing, to unlade or ≈øell and make away the Goods in controver≈øie, unle≈øs it happen to be done by con≈øent of parties, and to prevent the peri≈øhing of the ≈øaid Goods and Merchandi≈øe.

div.head: XXXVIII.
div.p: The ≈øaid Kings ≈øhall have in each others Court their Mini≈øters, and in certain Ports their Con≈øuls, for the better and more ea≈øie communicating and propo≈øing ≈øuch things, as they ≈øhall think advantageous to the Publick intere≈øt, or private concerns of any particular Per≈øon.

div.head: XXXIX.
div.p: No Private injury ≈øhall in any wi≈øe letten this Treaty, nor ≈øhall rai≈øe any di≈øcord or hatred between the fore≈øaid Nations, but every man ≈øhall an≈øwer for his own doings, and ≈øhall be re≈øpon≈øible therefore; Nor ≈øhall one man ≈øuffer for that which another has offended in, by having recour≈øe to Repri≈øals, or ≈øuch like rigorous proceedings, unle≈øs ju≈øtice be denied or delayed longer then is fitting. In which ca≈øe it ≈øhall be lawful for that King, who≈øe Subject has received the Injury, to proceed according to the rules and pre≈øcriptions of the Law of Nations untill reparation be made to the party injured; Provided notwith≈øtanding that he have fir≈øt in due manner adverti≈øed the other King thereof.

div.head: XL.
div.p:
Al≈øo it is Agreed that if the Hollander, or any other Nation what≈øoever (the Swedi≈øh Nation onely excepted) hath already, or ≈øhall hereafter obtain any better Articles, Agreement, Exemptions or Priviledges then what are contained in this Treaty from the King of Denmark, that the ≈øame and like Priviledges, ≈øhall be likewi≈øe Granted to the King of Great Britain, and His Subjects effectually and fully to all intents and purpo≈øes; And on the other≈øide if the Hollander or any other Nation what≈øoever, hath or ≈øhall obtain from His Maje≈øty of Great Britain, any better Articles, Agreements, Exemptions or Priviledges then what are
contained in this Treaty, that the ≈øame and like Priviledges ≈øhall be granted to the King of Denmark and His Subjects al≈øo, in mo≈øt full and effectual manner.

div.head: XLI.
div.p: It is al≈øo Concluded, That former Treaties and Leagues at any time heretofore made between the fore≈øaid Confederates or their Predece≈ø≈øors Kings, as well for the Kingdoms of Great Britain, &c. as for the Hereditary Kingdoms of Denmark and Norway, &c. re≈øpectively, be not in the lea≈øt reputed or taken to be broken and aboli≈øhed by any Agreement, Covenants or Articles in the pre≈øent Treaty contained; But that the ≈øame remain in full force, effect and virtue, ≈øo far as they are not contrary or repugnant to the pre≈øent Treaty or any Article therein contained.

div.head: XLII.
div.p:
Finally, it is Covenanted, concluded and agreed, that the fore≈øaid Kings ≈øhall ≈øincerely and bona fide ob≈øerve all and ≈øingular the Articles contained and ≈øet down in this Treaty, and ≈øhall cau≈øe them to be ob≈øerved by their Subjects and People; Nor ≈øhall tran≈øgre≈øs the ≈øame directly or indirectly, or ≈øuffer the ≈øame to be tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed by their Subjects or People, and ≈øhall Ratify and Confirm all and ≈øingular the premi≈ø≈øes as before Agreed, by Letters Patents Sub≈øcribed with their hands, and Sealed with their Great Seales in good ≈øufficient and effectuall form, and ≈øhall deliver the ≈øame reciprocally within three Moneths after the date of
the≈øe Pre≈øents, or cau≈øe them to be delivered, in good faith and reality, and with effect.
In the SAVOY, Printed by the A≈ø≈øigns of John Bill and Chri≈øtopher Barker, Printers to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, 1672.
